Award.AwardTitle: Dissertation Research: Molecular Systematics of Porroglossum orchids: Phylogenetics, Floral Snap-Trap Kinematics, and Fragrance
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project will study the evolutionary relationships of Porroglossum, an endangered Neotropical orchid genus are distributed in the Andes. The flowers of Porroglossum are unique because the labellum or 'lip' actively snaps inward when touched in order to trap pollinators and ensure successful pollination. The research will combine modern molecular approaches, high-speed videography, and floral fragrance sampling to gain a multifaceted understanding of the evolutionary relationships within the group and the processes underlying its diversification. This project will train both undergraduate and graduate students in modern molecular systematics techniques, including members of under-represented groups, and will enhance collaborations with orchid researchers in Ecuador.

This project aims to fully resolve phylogenetic relationships within the Neotropical orchid genus Porroglossum. Researchers will use reduced representation genome sequencing (e.g., genotyping by sequencing) to collect a large number of SNPs from each species within the genus. The project also will use high-speed videography to examine floral snap-trap kinematics among species of Porroglossum. Velocity, acceleration, and kinetic energy data will be collected from high-speed videos of the active floral snap-traps and mapped onto the fully resolved phylogenetic tree, and phylogenetic signal will be estimated for each data type. Lastly, this research will employ dynamic headspace adsorption and a gas chromatography/mass spectrometry instrument to investigate the patterns of floral fragrance evolution within Porroglossum.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This research project reconstructed the evolutionary history of Porroglossum, which is an exceedingly young orchid genus found in the Neotropics. Porroglossum has been estimated to have arisen between approximately 3 and 4 Mya. Young lineages of plants have proven to be troublesome for systematists in the past because there is a lack of sequence variation to resolve relationships among taxa using traditional methods such as Sanger Sequencing. In particular, we utilized high-throughput sequencing technology (i.e., genotyping-by-sequencing) to generate thousands of short sequences, known as loci, that span the entire genome, which as a whole can be utilized to resolve relationships among young lineages of plants. As a result, we were able to address three main research objectives which are as follows: 1) To assess the phylogenetic utility of genotyping-by-sequencing (GBS) at reconstructing the evolutionary history of Porroglossum; 2) To analyze floral snap-trap kinematics among species of Porroglossum through high-speed videography and statistical analyses; and 3) To investigate how phylogenetic conservatism of ecological niches varies among clades within Porroglossum in regard to their floral fragrance. In doing so, the CoPI made several trips to Gualaceo, Ecuador to conduct research in the greenhouses of Ecuagenera (e.g., data collection in the realm of kinematics and fragrance sampling), which is one of the largest orchid nurseries in the world. 

In regard to research objective number one, our resulting GBS phylogeny was a vast improvement over the previous phylogeny that was produced through traditional Sanger Sequencing. In particular, we were able to produce a fully-resolved phylogeny that addressed interspecific relationships within clades and deep internal nodes. Additionally, we found that there are clear discrepancies between the taxonomic classification set forth by Carl Luer (1987) based on morphology and our molecular phylogeny, which is most likely due to morphological convergence. As a result, our GBS phylogeny not only provides the first account of evolutionary relationships among species of Porroglossum, but also provides insight for future conservation efforts because we now have a better understanding of how these orchids are related.

For research objective number two, we analyzed floral snap-traps for 33 species of Porroglossum and found considerable intraspecific variation in the length of time until snap-trap closure, which may be indicative of the age of the flower, the varying ambient temperatures at which videos were recorded, and/or other unknown factors. Additionally, we found that there was strong phylogenetic signal when using both Pagel's λ and Blomberg's K statistic indicating that closely related species resemble one another more than expected by chance in relation to the time that it takes for the active snap-trap to close. Furthermore, we detected three evolutionary shifts in trait evolution including the following: a shift to slow snap-traps for the Porroglossum clade, a shift back to fast snap-traps for two species within the aforementioned clade, and a shift to a slow snap-trap for one species (P. eduardii) within Brevisepala, a clade exhibiting species with fast snap-traps. Lastly, variance among species in regard to the snap-trap's velocity and acceleration were congruent with the time to snap-trap closure. 

In reference to research objective number three, we measured the amounts of 53 compounds emitted from the flowers of ten Porroglossum species, including green leaf volatiles, monoterpenes, sesquiterpenes, and benzenoids. While we found a large diversity of compounds, most species emitted only a small subset of the total, however the range was considerable. For instance, only 11 compounds were emitted from the flowers of P. porphyreum but P. tripollex had 39 of the total 53 chemicals found in its bouquet. Most of the volatiles seen in P. tripollex were not present in any of the other species and included several related monoterpenes (e.g., neral, geraniol, geranial, neryl acetate, geranyl acetate, trans-geranic acid methyl ester, and trans-geranyl acetone). In addition, this species was very rich in sesquiterpenes, emitting relatively high levels of cis-α-bergamotene, farnesyl acetate, bisacurol, and sesquisabinene. Compounds emitted in the highest amounts included linalool, cis-linalool oxide, and benzaldehyde. Linalool was found in the emissions of all species and ranged almost 400-fold with the highest amounts produced by P. muscosum "yellow" flowers and the lowest from P. lycinum. Most species emitted relatively low amounts of linalool, except for P. dreisei, which contained about six times less than P. muscosum "yellow" flowers. We detected benzaldehyde in the bouquets of all species, except P. porphyreum, but only P. muscosum "yellow" and P. peruvianum produced large amounts of this benzenoid. Ultimately, total emissions differed greatly between the ten species with P. muscosum "yellow" plants emitting the highest levels of total compounds and four times than the next highest species, P. peruvianum.
